positive.review:
The reviews for this game are mixed because frankly, the game launched in an extremely buggy state. However, the developers have demonstrated that they care about this game and have consistently addressed issues as they have arisen. If you enjoyed For the King 1 the game is now in a state where I would be happy to recommend.

It is a significant improvement over the first game, significantly more content and a much deeper combat system than the previous. While I believe some of the initial poor reviews were warranted, the developers have shown that they care about the game and their players. Do not be scared off by the initial reviews, this is an excellent co-op game and is worth picking up!

üìùI thought the first For The King was a great beer-fueled game with friends, but it turns out it's the second one that takes the cake.

üß†The sequel is more linear and is in a way stricter with the plot. However, some missions provide enough time for exploring, particularly if you slow down the chaos in the settings of difficulty. 
The fighting has turned out to be much more appealing, with an implicit tactical aspect added. Though it doesn't blow the mind, it was certainly absent in the first installment. At the beginning, it does not look much different but gradually you realize how the engagement of the game is increased so much by it.
And the signature dice continue to be present, together with the shouts of "what the hell," the swearing aimed at the unpredictability, and the cheers when you unexpectedly one-shot someone. The game has become less casual and more mobile-like, which is a credit to it.
For The King 2 has truly become deeper, more self-assured, more interesting, and most importantly, more fun.

The game features several character classes: blacksmith, mage, archer, shepherd, and others - each with their own unique abilities and skills.We can personalize the heroes in various ways by selecting different combinations of weapons, armor, and accessories, thus giving them a unique playstyle.
This is a role-playing game with tactical elements. The player controls a group of heroes traveling through locations in search of adventure and treasure. They must fight enemies, solve puzzles, and interact with the environment to achieve their goals.

‚úÖThe Good.
+ Great alternative to board games
+ Engaging storyline
+ The visual style has been beefed up
+ There are now 4 characters instead of 3
++ Perfect with beer and games with friends.++

‚ùåThe Bad.
- Very minor improvements compared to the initial release
- In the multiplayer mode, there is a battle for the spoils
- Early game is tougher compared to late game.
- The time limit in some missions makes it difficult to enjoy the exploration of the map, thus killing the fun.

It's still the same For The King, only now it's bigger and has mechanics missing from the first game. One of the major things is the option to have a maximum of 4 players in a party, which can now be played in groups of 2 (2x2) or 4. The shop is also very much extended with the addition of the new classes. You can recruit mercs in the town that help you to eventually have a party of 8 people (mercenaries act automatically during the fight). You can also pick up items for your starter at the start, and as you progress through the game, more pleasant perks become available. The combat system also now features the concepts of first and second lines, something missing from the first game. Of course, this doesn't mean everyone will kick the sole character in the front row.

üßæSummary.
For The King 2 is a game that is at a crossroads between the past and the coming era of the franchise. It keeps a large portion of the previous game‚Äôs visuals, mechanics, and story but at the same time brings in its own innovations. However, the game, despite its innovations, is unable to create its own personality and is forever tied to the first game. This identity crisis along with the loading times which happen too frequently to be just minor inconveniences lead to a game that had to go through the pain of being uninteresting and irritating before it could ever be enjoyable.
7.5/10üîö
üìùThe changes the developers have implemented have positively affected the game and made it a real successor to the classic. For those who were disappointed back then, it is definitely worthwhile to try again now.

Genre - Turn based rogue or adventure game with optional Co-op
It's a 6.5/10 game for me, but still fun for a few games, so maybe get on sale.
There are 3 distinct ways of playing. The rogue mode, the adventure mode, or co-op mode.
+ It has hot seat mode
+ The characters and enemies are varied.
+ The rogue mode can be fun up to a point.
+ Loads of weapons, items to find (in small quantities).
+ The mini-boss fights can be well balanced.
+ Permanent upgrades and characters to unlock (but limited to keeping game at a similar balance).
- Rogue (Dark Carnival) - The difficulty and balance is silly. On rogue mode the enemies get too hard, too quickly and healing and treasure is too limited. With loads of negatives to pick up that counter act any positives. Also someone had the bright idea to always put a party of 5 enemies against your party of 4. Literally if it was 4 enemies as standard, the balance would be a lot better. Especially as party members can die and not be replaced.
- Adventure modes - You will need to play on the easiest mode to progress. Similar issues as above, but in this your party can get split too easily, even though you might be fighting smaller numbers of foes. There is a map, so you can be more tactical, but you are working against the clock.
I haven't played co-op, but it's not going to give you any advantages, if anything it's more likely to mean the party are working against each other. I'm sure it'll be fun. But progress will be hindered by bad balance again.
A shame, as if this game was balanced fairly, it could have been a lot more fun to play and progress.

Personally I love FTK2 even more than FTK1, and I really really love FTK1. I feel like FTK2 does everything even better! I have a few buddies that don't like that you can't rotate the camera (which is a valid complaint), but it doesn't bug me too much and I still think this is a great game for playing with friends.

I honestly didn‚Äôt expect the game to impress me this much üòÑ. The visual style, overall presentation, and the way everything is delivered feel genuinely top-tier ‚Äî you can clearly see the developers put a lot of heart into crafting this world. The atmosphere pulls you in right away, and every location looks polished and full of detail ‚ú®. Even though the gameplay felt a bit unusual at first, it quickly grew on me, and I found myself enjoying the challenge and the variety it offers.

The more I played, the more I appreciated how well everything fits together üéÆ. The pacing, the combat flow, and the small touches in animations and sound design really helped keep the experience engaging. By the end, I could confidently say it was absolutely worth my time üòä. If you enjoy strategy adventures with personality and strong visual identity, I genuinely recommend giving it a try ‚Äî it‚Äôs a surprisingly rewarding journey üåü.

i tried the free week, it didn't take a week i enjoy this game. if you need a break and a good way to relax this is for you. if you don't enjoy games that don't require a lot of thought, you might want to pass it up. there's no voiced dialog, and its a hex crawler but the story is good enough to keep you entertained and the gameplay keeps you engaged.

For The King 2 has a more visually appealing look than its predecessor. Very silly but fun game... turn based shenanigans, stat abuse, and hilarious ragdoll physics combined with the accessibility features (blood is instead confetti, also arachnophobia mode turns spiders into essentially floating loaves of bread (no legs) which both are just silly and fun while addressing the needs of people who need no spooders or no blood) make this a game that is great fun with friends. It's getting regular updates, and while things are not perfect, I do recommend it.

üí¨Following the success of For the King, IronOak Games has returned with a sequel, immersing players even deeper in the world of strategic combat and cooperative gameplay. For the King II seeks to not only keep the main traits of the original game that fascinated us, players, for hours but also to go deeper into the mechanics to provide us with an even richer experience.

üéÆWhen one looks at FtK II for the first time, they see the well-known features of the previous game: turn-based fighting, exploring, and playing together. Nevertheless, everything has been redone, made more interesting with new classes, equipment making, and the addition of a fourth character who is supposed to add more tactical depth to the game. The combat system is the remarkable alteration that attracts attention mainly. The fights are held on a grid now, and with the extra party member, new strategies can be devised. Players have to think of every move as in a chess game, as unit placement on the board will be very important.

However, the range of new classes is kind of disappointing though. The developers have tried their best to add new functionalities but sometimes it feels like they are just repeating what is already there. The loadout system, while seemingly allowing for customization, doesn't fully fill this gap.

Exploration is the second foundation of the game, which is a mixture of map reading, resource management, and strategic decision-making. Each campaign has a certain amount of variation thanks to the procedural generation of maps, but the visible differences are often just cosmetic and not much of an impact on gameplay. This shows another unexploited potential area.

The narrative of the game unfolds in a captivating manner, instantly throwing the players into the scenes that happened after the first game. Even though the storyline is not the main focus and the character interactions are limited, the game world is not lacking in charm. The characters while charming and friendly, are nonetheless, deprived of complete development and interaction with the world, which, in a way, takes the depth from the story that could have been the case.

The game's visuals and audio are superb, immersing the player in a fairytale world full of color and detail. While the music is pleasant to the ear, it may not be memorable. FtK II adds the player experience with a more challenging difficulty level compared to the first game. The fights with enemies have become harder, and players have to think well and control their resources to win. This higher difficulty level introduces an additional dose of excitement and tension, giving each decision a significant impact on the game's outcome.

While fate plays a role in combat, the Focus system gives players the ability to manipulate fortune to their advantage. The limited-focus points that can be restored by either resting or using healing items are a tactical instrument. They mitigate the negative impact of randomness and increase the chances of survival. This system not only increases combat but also motivates the players to make the right choices and plan their resource allocation in a smart way.

The progression system has its pros and cons. On one hand, going through the campaign and gaining access to the new character classes, places, and items that will encourage continued play, the available options in the Lore Store can feel somewhat limited. This can have a negative effect on replayability, more so because a lot of the new classes are just slight changes to the basic characters.

The game excels in multiplayer. Co-op play allows you to invite friends, further enhancing the game's tactical appeal. While managing multiple characters in single-player mode can sometimes feel monotonous, the presence of friends significantly enhances exploration and combat. The whole process of adding friends and going on an adventure together is simple and easy to use, which makes multiplayer a perfect way to experience the game completely.

While FtK II is an engaging and rewarding game, a weakness is the inability to view your party's stats and equipment while acquiring new items or loot. In the case of obtaining weapons and armor, the problem is very clear, the interface does not allow comparing statistics and picking the best counterpart to use the items. The introduction of that capability would not only make the process much easier but also enhance the game in general.

Another missing key element is the power to deploy your team on the board before the fight, which looks very important in the games that rely on tactics and strategic deployment. This restriction can cause unpleasing feelings and also the loss of positions that might have been good for you in combat. It is certain that the pre-battle deployment would considerably improve the tactical aspects of the game and make the fighting much more interesting.

üëçStrengths.
- Hard to master‚Ä¶
- Intuitive and Addicting Combat System
- New combat system
- New polished visuals

üëéWeaknesses.
- Annoying Loading Screens
- Imbalanced Metagame Progression
- Lack of Distinction From The Previous Game
- ‚Ä¶hard to master

üèÅSummary.
For the King 2 is a basic turn-based game that offers great experiences, albeit with a simple design: It is in fact a good game with a beautiful graphics that is also a mixture of challenging and funny quest fantasy RPG that can give you new experiences either alone or with others during first, second, or tenth playtime sessions, with lots of character in the process. The graphics are a bit tired but the bad ones are still present in the user interface that hinders what should be a very fluid gameplay. The puzzles of where to go, how to find a dungeon that is missed and how to kill a strong enemy are the pleasant ones; the puzzles of how and when your Farmer makes a scarecrow are rather unpleasant ones.
üéØ7/10

There's this tendency for games to not have working in-game chats:
- Chat is blank when opened, even if there are existing messages. You have to scroll to see the existing messages.
- Chat keeps minimizing itself.
- Everything locks when you enter chat, including camera momentum. Why? Locking keyboard hotkeys makes sense but why everything else?
- Chat exits text box while things happen for other players, even in the middle of typing (I have to re-enter the chat box several times to type a single sentence). So the chat has now entered a new unique state where it's visible but not usable.
- Chat locks up if you type too many characters. You can no longer use the chat unless you restart the game.
- And if you enter even more characters, the game freezes completely. An unlikely scenario, but it feels like this should have been tested more for a $33 game (it's fine on sale)

Learning the mechanics takes some time if you're coming from DnD or other more traditional RPGs. That said when you get it, it clicks well and becomes very fun. My only gripe about it is the way it handles attacks. So to attack your character has to make X number of rolls related to one of their stats and you can spend focus to guarantee rolls. So you spend your focus or get lucky/have high stats to make that perfect roll and oh enemy dodged it. This makes no sense to me coming from a DnD perspective. A perfect roll should mean I not only performed my attack really well but actually landed it, other wise what's the point? If the enemies evasion is good that should make it harder for me to land my rolls rather that a perfect roll going to waste at least for me. That said, other than that personal gripe, I'm very into the game.

I only game casually but I loved the first For The King, and I thought this was a solid sequel. It expands the game (more characters, more mechanics) but also manages to be more beginner-friendly with a good tutorial and a campaign mode that's split into several shorter but still satisfying chunks.

There are also things I didn't like though. I feel like there may be too many characters now with nothing particularly new to offer, and this version of the game somehow feels slower (perhaps because there's 4 characters?). With these new additions, the game gives you new things to take in and learn to play with, but it may also be a little bogged down by all this. The more minimalist original was lightning in a bottle.

I hear the game had a buggy release and that put a lot of people off but I can recommend the version I played. I may not find it amazing like the first one, but it may actually be a good way into the franchise, and I definitely also recommend it if you're a fan of the original. This sequel really gives you that sense of revisiting an old friend.

Coming from someone who really enjoyed FTK 1, this is a solid game. The overall reviews aren‚Äôt great because the game launched in a rough state, but the devs have clearly put in the work and introduced a lot of meaningful improvements. If you liked For The King 1, the current state of this game will definitely intrigue you.

The main gameplay remains very familiar, but the combat improvements have genuinely won my heart. The addition of tiles, the extra row, and the ability to reposition your character during combat add a whole new layer of strategy and give you far more control over battle outcomes. Fights also feel much less RNG-dependent now. Plus, the addition of pets and companions is a very welcome touch.

However, the UI is not that great and definitely needs work. I‚Äôm confident the devs will polish it up.

Multiplayer and Progression Systems were greatly improved,

but holy moly does the UI sucks fucking ass. in multiplayer it keeps opening the inventory of whoever is currently taking a turn, when you inspect an item in someone's inventory it compares to the items THEY are wearing, not yours. the inventory window keeps closing all the time whenever anyone does anything, same with shop windows. these are my the major gripes.

Example: when selecting an attack, you can use focus to make it have a better chance of hitting. However, you need to click or select the attack, since just hovering will make you stay to the default action, which is usually the basic attack, while it wouldn't be too bad most of the time, my friends and I had some issues where the focus and attack plan got derailed by the fact the attack we wanted didn't get selected correctly. Another issue we faced was that we found the UI both too small and cluttered, as it made things that were important for continuing the campaign very hard to see or not important things took up way too much space. As well as the camera angle is usually pretty bad, so it makes the fights just unpleasant to look at. In conclusion, the game is great fun. I think for the king 2 greatly expands on the first game in many ways, most ways good, but occassionally I still find the same frustrations here and there. I enjoy playing on the medium difficulty, I think the game gives not only a huge challenge, but also it remains flexible enough that you do need to pay attention to your moves and actions to find success in a run. 

I enjoy that there seems to be a larger story role over arching in this game, the campaigns are slightly shorter than the first, which is great, the games UI seems a tad more flushed out and easier to work with. Some hiccups are still there but its much easier to navigate on mouse and keyboard for sure. 

My biggest frustration is the hardest difficulty, it cripples you so much right from the start, but for a game thats based on chance rolls, it can become hugely frustrating when it almost seems unfair at times. 

Aside from that I would recommend its pretty solid, if you enjoyed the first, this one you will most likely love.

For The King 2 strikes a great balance between the freedom of a D&D campaign and the feeling of a Dungeon Master who really, really doesn‚Äôt want the party to go off-script. It can be punishing sometimes a ‚Äúlearning opportunity‚Äù costs you the entire run. Overall the difficulty curve feels fair once you understand how the systems fit together.

For your first few adventures, I strongly recommend sticking to the Apprentice difficulty. It gives you room to experiment without instantly getting wiped for every mistake. Once you‚Äôve grasped the mechanics and the flow of encounters, you can confidently move on to the tougher campaigns.

The replay value is fantastic... which is good, because every time you bring in a new friend, they‚Äôll inevitably want to start from the beginning so everyone‚Äôs on the same page. Thankfully, the game‚Äôs design makes those do-overs feel fresh rather than tedious. The game keeps the same broad strokes and quests each run, but the constantly changing maps and unpredictable encounters ensure every campaign still feels unique.

Gameplay and Strategy
Many reviewers praise "For the King II" for refining turn-based roguelike mechanics, offering deep tactical combat, new quest types, and supporting up to four players in co-op mode. The procedurally generated worlds and the addictive gameplay loop have kept fans returning for more, with challenging battles that require strategic use of resources and planning.

Critic and User Ratings
The game has averaged a score close to 78 from critics, with most reviews marked as "Mostly Positive" on Steam, reflecting fan enjoyment. Some call it a near-perfect sequel, especially for groups of friends playing together, and appreciate that bugs are gradually being fixed.

Design, Controls, and Bugs
However, enthusiasm is tempered by criticisms: the game‚Äôs controller support is described as buggy and poorly tested, leading to user frustration especially for those coming from the first game. Issues include difficulty navigating menus, camera angles that detract from combat enjoyment, occasional freezes, and lack of clear information about abilities and mechanics. These problems are compounded for solo players or those expecting smooth local co-op like the original.

Challenge and Accessibility
Difficulty is a constant theme, with some players finding the punishing mechanics rewarding, while others struggle and attribute negative feedback to steep learning curves and lack of robust tutorials. When played online, bugs may interrupt gameplay, but the community generally agrees balancing and the core gameplay loop are strong, once the controls are mastered.

This is going to be my first negative review here but I think after 35 hours I can safely say it's not based on first impressions. Now, the experience might be different for someone who only encounters For the King through this second version of it, it's a decent game and if there was a middle option between yes and no that's where I'd put it. Maybe I'd love it if I hadn't played the original. I am however a veteran player - For the King was pretty much the first game I ever played and I've played a lot of it - and For the King II undoubtedly pales in comparison in my opinion.

First some good things: I quite like the idea of the new fight mechanics that in theory make your and the enemy's placement more important. In practice so far in my games it doesn't matter nearly enough for me to have to strategize around it except on a very basic level - enemies in a tight group good for bomb or mage stand behind shield bearer. And I don't play on the easiest difficulty. Row and column attacks and so on are nice though! Also I love the pets! Wanting to keep them alive has so far been the only truly motivating and difficult thing for me as you have to think mid-battle about how to place yourself to be able to heal them or keep them safe when their health falls low. There's a few comfort of life changes I appreciate as well.

Other than that I am mostly unsatisfied though. It uses largely the same exact enemies and bosses as the first game so I am rarely surprised and it feels very much like the same game except more 3D in style and with a few extra characters and mechanics dropped in. The progress feels faster which might be fun for some players but for me takes away the challenge of those early rounds where you are weak and squishy and every upgrade you get is exciting - it feels like you get too strong too fast and if my character has died it's been because the ease of it made me lazy and I stopped thinking and did something stupid. And I repeat, I don't play in easy mode! Even though there's visually more noise and seem to be more choices you have to click on, I spend so many fights just hitting the same button on repeat and winning which annoys me more in this case than the first game since it looks more complex but it's rarely necessary to interact with all the options. I guess that's my FTK experience speaking, I saw some other people in negative reviews say it's too punishing - for me it's been the opposite. Not that I'd prefer it to be punishing, but I'd like for decisions to feel more important. Also after a while there's simply nothing more to upgrade or improve on which happened in the original too but I feel like maybe not so fast. Also why cap at 9 levels?

The challenge mode (Hildebrant's cellar vs Dark Carnival) suffers under the same issue: the characters start out stronger right away, facing stronger enemies, but instead of being more challenging, it's easier. You never get the weakling with a stick phase, and upgrade/level pretty fast into "none of these enemies scare me at all except if some stupid coincidences overlap and they one-hit me" and then the enemies just repeat and repeat and repeat with not much change. In Hildebrant's cellar going deeper felt meaningful until you hit a plateau deep enough down, I enjoyed starting it again even if I'd played it a lot already, because the starting position could influence your entire build. In Dark Carnival after you get the hang of it and kit out your characters a bit it's all the same all the way down. At least we didn't encounter anything new in 30 floors or so. We did die eventually but it didn't feel like the result of a challenge, as it didn't really get more difficult, just cut off your healing opportunities and gave the enemies +x amount of health, which I don't find interesting. Just the same fight but longer.

It very much has the "second game syndrome" of making me ask was it really necessary after the first good game to make the same game again? And unlike some where the second game is same but even better or same but more, I don't feel either better or more. I'll keep playing and maybe as the storylines progress something new pops up but so far it just makes me want to play the original again except I've done everything it's possible to do there. It's not like bad bad or anything and whatever bugs there were when it launched seem to be fixed, it's just... fine, i guess?

I think the changes might be geared towards new players who might appreciate getting stronger faster as they're figuring out the game mechanics. Perhaps people craved a faster-paced adventure? Though it's probably not as fast for a beginner. When you already know how everything works (almost the exact same way as the first game) and have seen all the main bosses and encounters and so on you just kinda go why? Did the original game's code break so you can't update it? Did you have to switch programs so you decided to redo it with minimal changes? I do of course still wish all the best to the team :)

I hope as I progress and they add new content things improve for me but I'm not sure how much longer I can keep going before getting too bored and/or annoyed to continue.

PS: all the female body types are so... idk how to say it. Like there's Big Lady and Small Lady but their faces and hairdo look so similar and so nothing compared to the different types of men. I've had to be playing all bearded dudes just because none of the ladies look like a human being. Not from a beauty point of view, rather the opposite. UI in this game, doubly so for controller players it shockingly bad and frustrating to use and navigate around. For instance your character has multiple moves they can choose from a list, multiple enemies they can target, and a special resource called focus to increase hit chance. Every time you start a round your character targets the first enemy by default, and your 1st move is selected. (nothing wrong with this). Now, lets say you select the 3rd enemy, and your 2nd move, and you use 2 focus. 

well here's what happens. first, the moment you use focus your players move menu will shrink down to just icons so you can no longer read it. There is absolutely no reason for this since it's not like it's making room for any other ui elements. Once the menu is hidden like this it's not clear what move you have selected, making it easy to get into situations where your questioning, "wait did i apply focus before selecting my move?". Well at least you can hit the back button to unhide the menu again. Except be careful because doing so will change your move selection back to your first move. But even more infuriating, is the second you clicked a to use your ability, it will change the selection back to the first enemy, remove your focus, but keep the 2nd move selected. So now you need to remember to re select the correct enemy a second time and re apply you'r 2 focus in order to complete your move. This make it extremely easy to accidently target the wrong enemy, or fail to apply focus. This is made worse by the fact that focus is a rare resource often used in important life or death situations. The number of times I've gone to attack an enemy with focus, only to fail to apply it, or worse yet remember to re apply it but select the wrong move because the game likes to randomly change your selected move is multiple. 

Secondly, lots of info is poorly conveyed or not conveyed at all. So info seems impossible to view unless you use a mouse, but even with a mouse there are bits of information that are not conveyed at all. Take this other example. I chose to play a herbalist since it sounded like a medic and starts with a cure ability. This being a turn based game, wasting even a single move to effectivly do nothing is extremely bad. So while in game, if you hover over cure, there is zero description unlike some other moves. It just says cure. Ok well i tried to use it to heal and alley, it did nothing and completely wasted my turn. Extremely annoying, the only silver lining, I had a suspicion it might only be for healing status aliments, though it would of been really nice to know that before hand. Ok fine, lesson learned moving on right? But later in the game in an intense boss fight were one of my characters is nearly dead, he get's an aliment that called unwell that reduces vatality by 30 points. That sounds really bad, so instead of using my powerful mage attack move to kill a powerful enemy that's about to do damage i decide to use cure on the ally with this aliment. Excepts guess what, It does nothing, becuase apparently cure doesn't even heal all stat aliments just some of them. But again 0 indication in game about what those might be. And because this is a turn based game with each encounter only afew rounds back an fourth, trying to take time to test out stuff like this manaully to naturally increase you're knowledge of what it does and doesn't work on is extremely disadvantagous.  But even if you wanted to play devils advocate and say it's intended game design and they want you to discover that naturally. Well at the very least that should be conveyed in the non existant description for cure. something like "may cure some stat aliments but not all". BTW, turns out that aliment I had was a curse, had to look it up online. Zero indication anywhere in ui that that was the case. 

I'll end with this though don't be fooled there are even more ui issues. There are various tile effects that can be applied naturally via weather or abilities. But there is zero indication of what they do. For example there is a wet tile. what does it do? who know, it doesn't seem like casting lightning does extra damage to people on wet squares. Maybe it makes you slower and hence lower in move order? But idk for sure. But standing it it evenetually  will make a wet status effect show up. does that mean it does nothing untill your marked wet? Also i could be misremembering this part but i'm pretty sure despite a wet alert showing up, there actually is no status aliment indicator above your character portrat, so i don't think it's a true status aliment the way other aliments exist. However, this also makes it extemey unclear when you character is wet or not. And this is just one of multiple tiles, but as of yet it's unclear to me what any of the different tiles i come across due since they seem to be less obvious stat changes. 

The game otherwise is actually good and i loved the first game, but actually WTF is this interface. It completely ruins the game for no reason, an 95% of it seems like common sense alterations could completely solve the issue.

As of right now, I would only recommend buying FTK2 if it is on sale. There are many improvements from the first game, such as the ability to play with a party of four and numerous quality of life changes. The overall difficulty is also easier with the addition of pets, mercenaries, changes to healing item scaling, and more plentiful loot. However, the game still has noticeable bugs almost 2 years after its initial release, the UI is a downgrade from the first game, and there are some clearly imbalanced characters.

I can't actually believe how bad this UI is. The game itself is pretty fun (more of the same from the first really), but the UI makes it such a drag to do anything or find things out (look at BG3 devs, you can pull up tool tips on literally anything via a click of a button. Chance to inflict RANDOM SYMBOL, and also not explain the effect, is a choice). 

It's just honestly embaressing that a team of developers made this UI, tested it and thought 'yeah, this is really good'. It ruins the actual fun game hiding behind this interface.

Obligatory - "I don't normally write reviews but"... but this UI is so grating that it's inspiring me to do try and actively convince others (for their own sanity) to not play this game because no one should have to subject themselves to this war crime of a UI.

Gave it a shot during the free weekend. Found it to be incredibly confusing and absolute sensory overload with how much information it immediately hits you with. It has all of the elements of TTRPGs, but lacks the elements that make those kinds of games fun. It's just a bunch of numbers you have to keep track of and a bunch of clunky UIs that are hard to keep track of. If you're a fan of turn-based RPGs, this is not that. If you're a fan of TTRPGs, this is not that. If you're a fan of roguelikes, this is not that. It's a fine game to try, but if you really want a game like this, just buy the first one. It's at least a little easier to consume.
